Hey <@U10LM0FFZ> (Nick), do you want me to spend some time on this, and give you some detailed feedback?
I’m asking, as your version is already better and I can either approve it, or work with you on some small things that I see.
(Don’t know if you have noticed, I “suffer” from some OCD that sometimes comes in handy)
let's improve improve improve .  I said it three times for your OCD :slightly_smiling_face:
Thank you, thank you, thank you :wink:
OK, I’m on it.
I love this sentence: *Not only does this configuration lay a huge computational burden on each peer, hindering scalability, but it also constricts important facets of privacy and confidentiality.*

<@U10LM0FFZ>: How about (regarding the old arch)

"Every peer can see the logic for every transaction." -> "Every peer can see the most minute (and at times) sensitive detail/logic of every transaction."

<@U11MANG9G> Will do. Yes, this interface is documented in<https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Qg7ZEccOIsrShSHSNl4kBHOFvLYRhQ3903srJ6c_AZE/edit?usp=sharing> and  and in <https://docs.google.com/document/d/18XDGqxb3pz4sTS6jTJod1KufRSC7rRA-O3PMT5cUsqY/edit>. I've talked to <@U1BC5A0F9> and she will update those documents accordingly

trying to sell this again :wink: <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/4787/> is needed for node SDK to support crypto materials (keys and certs, mostly) produced with non-fabric-ca CAs. in particular <@U0KM61BCP> <@U0PB67X4K> <@U0ZR63HLK> <@U11MANG9G>
:heavy_dollar_sign: Selling <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/4791/> (43 lines, trivial CR- just adding a method to an interface, nothing else) for the lowest bidder! :heavy_dollar_sign:

<@U13TWBRBL> ^ hmm..
well..
Its possible, but not good practice for production
As long as we agree 'import private keys to help with testing', +1 from me :slightly_smiling_face:

<@U10Q62R8X> so the procedure i have in mind goes like this:
- admin logs in to app node and does whatever is needed to enroll the node with CA, which generates the private key (and saved somewhere in the file system, hsm is a different matter so let’s assume this is all software managed) for the device and have the cert signed by whatever the CA
- now somehow the app needs to get the SDK to use the private key and cert
- find them and export to PEM files and put them into the standard “MSP config dir” structure
- SDK is pointed to it and will be able to load it in
in the above procedure, private key never leaves the device where it’s generated
@jhang : If you can implement PKCS8 private key , that might suffice for software based system.

I had a thought about this problem too for CA. Trying to implement this right now actually.
- I have no objection to SW BCCSP importing keys
- I taught PKCS11 to import keys as well (works with softhsm, but might not work with a 'properly configured' crypto card)

The thinking goes that BCCSP is just a crypto interface (at some point we should extract it from fabric and propose it to gophercon..) Its the code that needs to know how to use it

The concern I have is not if BCCSP can import keys, but if fabric relies on that behaviour exclusively. 

Have a look at Have a look at <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/4397/>

In particular <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/4397/8/lib/csp/testdata/ec-key.ski>
<@U13TWBRBL>  <@U10Q62R8X>  <@U221LL03Z>   conversation should go on fabric-sdk or fabric-crypto ?

What I am probably going to propose is, 
- get private key pem file, parse
    - if a SKI PEM header, great, how we should do it
    - else try to import key into currernt/default csp
<@U0UGH3X7X> heh.. perhaps
:innocent:

note that there is a problem I believe in the event producer, for which I had to compensate for in the end-to-end.js code with a 2 second pause after receiving the transaction event and before moving on to the next step (<https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1862>)
